review_blob: Bottle.  Pours dark orange, almost brown with a thick but quickly diminishing tan head.  Im honestly not sure what it is, but the aroma is very nice and fruity...sweet and malty, also.  I cant say much more about the flavor than it is also fruity, sweet and malty.  I dont have enough experience with the style to pick out individual flavors, but this is about as good as any barelywine-style ale that Ive had.  Very nice tasting and smelling.  Recommended.

Bottle.  Pours completely black, no highlights.  Head is dark tan and thick.  Aroma is roasty and smoky with chocolate notes.  Tastes more toasty than it smells with dark chocolate, caramel and slight alcohol flavor.  Right up there with Old Rasputin.

Bottle. Pours nice and dark with ruby highlights.  Thick, creamy, lasting head.  Smells of malt, caramel, toffee and plum.  Flavor is sweet and malty with caramel.  Im not up on the style, but I think its a very good quadruple.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy brownish orange.  Head was off white and thick, but dissipated after a minute or two.  Still there, just right on the surface, no higher.  Aroma is very hoppy and fruity.  The distinct aroma of grapefruit is very apparent.  Medium body with very strong hop bitterness.  Hop flavor is definitely there along with the grapefruit from the aroma.  In fact, if I didnt know any better, Id say they brewed this with grapefruit.  This is one of the best DIPAs Ive had.  Not over the top hoppy and the grapefruit character seals the deal for me.

Bottle.  Pours orange with no head, not even after a vigorous pour.  Ill be honest here, I dont much about the style, so my comments will be fairly vague, so I apologize.  Smells sour, as a lambic should with lots of fruit in the aroma.  Not a sour as I was expecting.  The sourness is pleasant, but theres a slight astringency in the finish and Im honestly not sure if its supposed to be there or not.  Its subtle enough that I feel like its part of the style, but I dont really care for it.  Im trying to judge the style and not let my personal preference interfere, but Id have to say this one is different than other lambics Ive had, so maybe its just that I havent tried enough lambics.  Perhaps Ill get another bottle and see how it does after a couple years of aging.

Bottle from release #1.  This is one dark porter.  Very small ruby highlights, but otherwise dark as night.  Thick, rockyish, light tan head.  Smells just like pumpkin pie except with some chocolate notes underneath.  So in other words, amazing!  Pretty sweet up front with vanilla and pumpkin pie flavors.  Cinnamon is definitely present and finishes with a soft chocolate bitterness.  One of the best porters to ever grace my palate.  I will now definitely try other Epic brews.
beer_name: Epic / DC Brau Fermentation Without Representation

review_blob: Bottle.  Deep orange pour with a thick, rocky, off white head.  Intense spicy and floral hop aroma in the nose.  Medium body with a hoppy hit upfront, but not as intense as the aroma would lead you to believe.  Balanced by a sweet finish that leaves leaves the hop bitterness on your tongue.  Very good DIPA.

Bottle.  Pours deep orange with a thick off white head that dissipates quickly but leaves a ring around the edge of the glass.  Aroma is spicy and floral with a strong but less prevalent malt aroma backing it up.  Medium-full mouth feel with intense but balanced hops up front.  Pretty sweet on the back end, but balances nicely with the hops.  The guy at the store said this was his favorite Imperial IPA and I dare say he made a wise choice.  Certainly not the best Ive ever had, but still very good.  Recommended.

Bottle.  Pours pitch black with a thick tan head.  Smells roasty, smoked and chocolatey.  Perhaps a bit off coffee as well, but if its there, its very muted.  Nice, full bodied beer.  Malt sweetness and chocolate dominate the flavor.  Theres only the slightest hint of alcohol, but it serves to "warm" the beer up a bit.  And at 11.5%, its hard not to notice the alcohol.  Overall, and I know its probably cliche by now, but this is one of the best RISs in existence, at least among them that you can get in the States.  Ive never had an imported one, so I am not sure.

Bottle poured jet black into a stout glass.  1/2" head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma is roasty with chocolate and coffee.  Full bodied beer that is silky smooth in the mouth.  Flavor is like the aroma, roasty with chocolate and coffee.  Not a bad stout, but pretty run of the mill.

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown with a lasting 1 inch, tan head.  Very malty aroma with caramel and coffee very present.  A little fruity as well, but secondary to the previously mentioned aromas.  Taste is very malty sweet.  Not quite barleywine caliber, but still very sweet.  Most certainly not a chugging beer.  Only the very slightest of alcohol notes, but they compliment rather than hinder the beer.  It does a good job of offsetting the sweetness a bit.  The mouthfeel is quite full and, dare I say, syrupy almost.  The caramel and coffee from the aroma are also present in the flavor and the finish is, as stated, sweet but offset by a slight bit of alcohol flavor.  Overall, another outstanding brew from Stone and one I would definitely recommend to lovers of big beer.

Bottle.  Pours deep orange with a 1/2" off white head.  Spicy hops with a hint of caramel in the nose.  The head is dissipating slightly as I write, but looks like its going to give some nice lacing.  Big malt taste with not as much bitterness as I expected.  The hop flavor is spicy, though and reminds me of Amarillo hops I used in an IPA I brewed a while back.  The bitterness, as well as more hop aroma, is starting to come out as the beer warms from cold to chilled, so I am happy to report that it indeed lives up to its classification as an Imperial IPA.  The mouthfeel is a solid heavy, as one would expect from an Imperial IPA.  Overall, this is a good Imperial IPA, but not nearly the best Ive ever had.  I do recommend it, however it will disappoint some.

Id call the color cherry wood.  The head was small and dissipated quickly.  Very malty aroma as per the style.  Also caramel.  Big beer with big body.  A solid medium, possibly medium-heavy.  Very sweet up front with the malty and caramel flavors showing themselves distinctly.  No hop aroma or flavor and on the barest bitterness to balance the big malty sweetness.  Its a simple beer, not overly complex, but with enough character to make it interesting.  Overall: recommended.

From a bottle pours a dark burnt orange and hazy which I think helps diffuse the light and make the color variations more subtle; a very beautiful beer.  A spicy, floral aroma hits you up front, but its not super strong.  Honestly I was expecting more hop aroma, but it still smells delicious.  A medium-light bodied beer, its just thick enough to feel substantial without being too viscous.  The hops hit you front along with the bitterness that requisite of an IPA.  The combination of different kinds of spicy from the hops and rye make a perfect pair.  The finish is somewhat dry, but theres just enough sweetness to it at the end to keep it from being too dry.  Overall, Id say this is an excellent beer for those who like hops, but hopheads will find it lacking.  And thats okay, because it wasnt brewed for hopheads.  I would certainly recommend this beer to anyone who asks.

Bottle, poured nice and dark with a 1/2" tan head and dark ruby highlights when held up to the light.  There is a strong scotch smell which is complimented by vanilla and caramel.  I just giggled with joy as I smelled this for the first time.  I love scotch whiskey and I think they found a way to make scotch disguised as a beer.  Theres a peaty, earthy tone to it that serves to enhance the scotch aroma.  Theres also roasted malt underlying the previously mentioned aromas.  Theres so much going on with the flavor, its hard to put it into words.  Up front youve got the vanilla and caramel which is supported by the roasty, earthy flavors and to finish it off, quite elegantly I might add, youve got very subtle flavor of scotch with a slight alcohol burn, which added to greatly to the perception that I was drinking scotch in beer form.  The body is medium to medium-light and felt pretty much as I expected it to.  Theres a bit of sweetness at the end which is balanced out by the alcohol burn.  I understand the alcohol burn is typically viewed as a detractor, but I find that it fits in very well with the flavor profile of this brew.  Top notch brew from New Holland.

Bottle poured into a stout glass.  About a half an inch head that dissipated within a few minutes.  This porter is darker than many stouts Ive seen.  Held up to the light I see deep mahogany instead of the lighter ruby color you typically get with porters and stouts.  Aroma is dominated by smoke and roasted grain, but each is subdued enough that it is not overpowering.  Medium bodied with the aroma being a small hint as to the flavor.  Very roasty and smoky.  Theres a hint of chocolate and perhaps some coffee in there, but its very subtle and compliments the upfront smoky, roasty flavors very well.  This finish is a little sweet as is to be expected for the style, but not too sweet.  Overall this has been my best porter experience in quite some time.  I highly recommend Bells Porter to lovers of dark beer.

First craft bdew I can immediately say I did not care for.  It smells great with the tangerine and bready aromas, but the finish, I feel, is fairly dry.  It tastes like theres actually some of the peel in the beer.  Not so bad Im not going to finish, but wont be having it again.

Very nice tan head that recedes fairly quickly.  Aroma is pleasant with some fruity notes as well as a little chocolate and spicy notes.  Very sweet, but not too sweet.  This is hands down my favorite style and this is a very good example.

Poured from a bottle into a British pub glass at slightly below room temperature.  Very persistent, thick, creamy, tan head.  The aroma is quite interesting and pleasurable.  Roasted malt is most apparent with caramel in the background.  The flavor is incredible, to say the least.  Roasted and caramel flavor predominate up front and finishes smooth and creamy, very nice full body.

A strong citrus hop aroma and beautiful copper color make this look and smell like a prime example of the style.  The flavor backs up the appearance and aroma with plenty of malt and a light residual sweetness to back up the moderately high bitterness (65 IBUs).  Finishes slightly dry and leaves a memory of the hop flavor on the palate, begging you to have another sip.  Great IPA overall and highly recommended.

Man, I love the smell of hops.  Nice orangy copperish color, very pleasing to the eye.  Poured with a decent off white head that left a lot of lacing on the glass.  Very bitter, as the label says.  All 85 of the IBUs alluded to on the label are there.  Citruisy flavor from the loads of finishing hops Im sure they used.  Overall, a great beer. but not an every day drinker.

Not my favorite style, but very good for what it is.  It has a very pleasant fruity, yeasty and slightly hoppy aroma.  The color is nice to look at and is appropriate for this style of beer.  The flavor of the beer is good.  Just the right amount of hop flavor without being too aggressive .  It also satisfies the taste buds and allows the memory to linger on the palate.  No bad after taste at all.  Very good beer.

Pours dark with a very small head.  It smells of chocolate and coffee, very enjoyable aroma.  Not a whole lot to the taste initially, but finishes with a strong coffee/chocolate taste that really hangs out on the palate.  Decent beer, not best, but Ive drank it more than once, so that counts for something.

Pours with a beautiful thick, tan head and dark body.  Aroma is very nice with a light chocolate smell that is not quite covered by the aroma of coffee.  It has a smoky taste that lingers on the palate.  Very good beer, as Rogue always seems to produce.  At least as far as my experience with them goes.

Orange pour with the slightest of heads.  Looks unfiltered, kind of like water does when its far too aerated, but orange.  Just on looks, it looks neither good nor bad, Ive never seen a beer that looks like this.  Not nearly as hoppy as expected, but theyre there with an aroma of fruitiness.  Taste:  definitely wasnt expecting that!  Its very thick in the mouth and is very sweet.  It hides the 21% very well, but I dont think Id necessarily call this a good beer.  The finish is nice and it sticks to the palate quite nicely.  Its hard to say, Im really on the edge with this one;  its like nothing Ive ever tasted before.  One thing I can say, its a slow sipping beer.  Anything more than a small sip is too overpowering.  Although I usually like this in a beer, what I dont like is when the characteristic is so present that I have to worry about taking too big a sip.  I heard a lot of good things about this before picking it up today and I have to say it doesnt live up to the hype.  While it was an interesting experience, its not really my style, and definitely not worth 8 dollars a bottle.

This is a great looking and smelling beer.  Pours black with a thick light brown head that looks absolutely magnificent.  Smells malty with a hint of hops and chocolate.  Tastes nice, not quite as good I as I was expecting based off reviews i read, but still an excellent beer that I will be drinking again.

Pours a nice, dark reddish brown with a thick off white head that quickly dissipates and hangs out around a finger or so.  Slightly hoppy aroma that I really enjoy.  Most of the flavor doesnt come out until the finish, but when it does, man its nice.  Slightly hoppy with a tasty bitterness.  Hazelnut really hangs out on the palate, great beer I think.
Not much to this beer, but it is drinkable.  Small head, hoppy aroma with a corresponding taste.  The palate, surprisingly, is better than I expected, though, I its slightly better than average.
beer_name: Green Valley Brewing Stone Mill Pale Ale

review_blob: Pours a nice black color with a thick tan head at first, but quickly dissipates to thin tanner head.  Smells delicious; you can definitely smell the chocolate all over the place with a slightly hoppy background.  It basically tastes like it smells, strong chocolate with a slight hop back ground.  Over all its a decent chocolate stout, but I prefer the Rogue Chocolate Stout over this one.

A little on the light side for me, not much to the aroma.  It looks nice though and has a thin but persistent head.  Taste is ok, but again, on the light side for me.  Decent all around IPA though that I would drink again if none of my other favorites are available.

Theres relaxing beer and theres working beer.  This is a working beer.  Goes down quick with little taste and is good for little more than continual drinking while working on the truck or mowing the lawn or something.

Wow.  This is my first Rogue beer.  Ive barely even poured it and already its the best looking beer Ive ever seen.  The thick tan head and extremely dark body is absolutely beautiful.  Also, I smell chocolate!  Very nice taste that finishes with a good taste of the chocolate I smelled before.  This is now my favorite beer.

Pours a nice gold color with a the slightest of heads that dissipates a lot, but never quite goes away completely.  The smell alone is simply intoxicating;  very strong hoppy smell is just great.  The favor is very nice, goes down smooth and the finish isnt that bitter at all.  Over all I think this is a great beer and would definitely recommend it to others.

First off, this beer just looks beautiful.  Nice and dark with a thick head that goes away quickly.  The aroma is nice and rich with a hint of chocolate.  Taste took me a little bit by surprise, but I really liked it after I got over the initial shock.  The mix of chocolate and coffee is delicious.  Im now a fan of Otter Creek.

Pours nice and has a very small head that dissipates quickly.  The aroma is decent, mostly malty and I could definitely stand it without getting uncomfortable.  For some reason the first sip had little taste, but subsequent sips held a nice flavor, not too strong with a not too bitter finish.  All in all, I seemed to like this beer more than others seem to have.

I thought this beer had a very nice aroma to it and suited the palate pretty well.  The flavor could have been less bitter on the finish, but overall the flavor was pretty nice.  I cant really compare it to other APAs because this is this the first APA Ive tasted, but overall it was enjoyable and I would drink it again.
